meta.name: 14-Day Program
meta.description: A first step toward freedom. This 2-week program helps you build foundations.

1.title: Understanding the cycle
1.lesson: Addiction follows a cycle: trigger → urge → behavior → temporary relief → guilt. Today, we identify your personal triggers.

exercise.prompt: What are the 3 situations that most often trigger your urges?

2.title: Urge surfing
2.lesson: An urge is like a wave: it rises, peaks, then falls. You don't need to fight the wave, just surf it until it passes. Average duration: 15-20 minutes.

exercise.prompt: Close your eyes. Observe the urge without judging it. Where do you feel it in your body? What's its intensity from 1 to 10?

3.title: My core values
3.lesson: Your values are your compass. When your actions align with your values, you feel peace. When they conflict, you feel dissonance.

exercise.prompt: What are your 3 most important values? (e.g., family, honesty, health, faith...)

4.title: The power of rules
4.lesson: If-then rules create positive automatisms. Instead of relying on willpower in the moment, you pre-program your response.

exercise.example: If I'm alone in the evening, then I go for a 10-minute walk.

5.title: Restructuring thoughts
5.lesson: Our automatic thoughts can trap us: 'Just once', 'I deserve it', 'It's too hard'. Learn to identify and challenge them.

exercise.prompt: What thought often comes before a relapse? What more realistic thought could replace it?

6.title: Environment matters
6.lesson: Modifying your environment is more effective than relying on willpower. Make the undesired behavior hard to access.

exercise.prompt: What concrete change can you make to your environment today? (e.g., phone in another room at night)

7.title: Gratitude and review
7.lesson: At the halfway point, take time to acknowledge your progress. Each day without relapse is a victory. Each resisted craving strengthens your brain.

exercise.prompt: Note 3 positive things from this first week.

8.title: Hidden emotions
8.lesson: Often, the urge hides an emotion: loneliness, stress, boredom, anger. Identifying the underlying emotion allows you to address the real need.

exercise.prompt: During your last strong urge, what emotion were you really feeling? What unmet need?

9.title: Building alternatives
9.lesson: Your brain needs new sources of healthy dopamine. Physical activity, social connection, accomplishments, nature...

exercise.prompt: List 5 healthy activities that bring you pleasure or satisfaction.

10.title: Anti-craving plan
10.lesson: A precise plan for difficult moments: what to do in the first 5 seconds, first 5 minutes, first hour.

exercise.prompt: When an urge comes, what will you do immediately?

11.title: Managing relapses
11.lesson: A relapse is not failure, it's data. What matters is what you learn from it and how you get back up. Shame prolongs the cycle.

exercise.prompt: If a relapse happened, how would you respond with kindness toward yourself?

12.title: Social support
12.lesson: Isolation fuels addiction. Authentic connection fights it. You don't need to share everything, just not be alone.

exercise.prompt: Who could be a support in your journey? (friend, family, group...) How could you strengthen that connection?

13.title: Long-term vision
13.lesson: Imagine your life in 1 year, 5 years, free from this addiction. What's different? This vision is your deep 'why'.

exercise.prompt: Describe your ideal life in 1 year, free from this addiction.

14.title: Review and commitment
14.lesson: You've completed 14 days. This is just the beginning, but it's a solid foundation. Remember: progress isn't linear, but every effort counts.

exercise.prompt: What commitment do you make for what's next? What lesson do you take from these 2 weeks?
